1066089677738913792.text: A WHERE EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM ...) can certainly use an index-only scan too, but would also have to go check the heap for any not-all-visible pages matching the WHERE clause, just the same as the count(*), just to be clear.  You might check out EXPLAIN (ANALYZE,BUFFERS) query

1066088633965387778.text: The reason for this is that an index-only scan is only "index only" as long the visibility map for the items shows that the items are on an "all visible" page, which wouldn't be the case for the just-inserted tuple, but probably would be for the other tuple (if one exists).

1066088369610985473.text: Not to be a pain, but neither of those assumptions is actually correct- chances are you'd have exactly the same number of pages used in both cases- each index page necessary to find the items, the VisMap page(s), and the heap page where the just-inserted tuple is.

I'm saying it was around from the beginning of IPC, and it will be around long after we're gone.

gRPC is more of a transport+schema for RPC. There are many transports for RPC (e.g. JSONRPC). It's a very elementary concept that is very portable, imo hence its longevity.

957256659780427777.text: Then he and his team engaged in - if not invented - ethical hacking. They physically hacked their IBM punch card machines so that nothing could be entered into column 11: religion. That data, for those thousands of people, was missing.

957256599986372609.text: In the background, he sifted through the data to find recruits for the French Resistance. He and his team went further than that. They did things like leave boxes of census records - thousands of people's data - in a back room, unprocessed.

957256538946785280.text: Rene Carmille had all the data about all the people. He saw what the Nazis wanted to do with that data. So he made a decision about what to do with it. He did his job, externally, for the Nazis, of course.

957256482785030144.text: Rene Carmille was the comptroller general of the French army. He eventually headed up the French census. Census data - innocuous, straightforward facts about people - was tabulated on IBM punch cards. Then the Nazis came.

957256845894316032.text:
As is his legacy. In the Netherlands, 73% of Dutch Jews were found, deported, and executed. In France, that figure was 25%. It was that much lower because they couldn't find them. 

They couldn't find them because Rene Carmille and his team got political and hacked the data.

Another big one: don’t worry too much about organizing the CANONICAL doc.

1103382230607581184.text:
I like @Dropbox Paper (over G Docs, etc) because it removes a lot of friction to keeping a CANONICAL document up to date:
- Sharing settings are "everyone can edit" by default
- Drag+drop to upload any kind of file
- Shows authorship
- Easy commenting
- "Looks and feels" nice

1103380735598227458.text:
With a CANONICAL doc, everyone on the project has a single entry point to everything pertaining to that project.

No more asking "what’s the staging URL again?" or "where can I find the spec docs?" - it’s all linked from, or contained in, CANONICAL.

Or 76g / 1.6k hours = 0.045g/hour

Contrast with the record, which is 500g of CO2, and plays for 44 minutes… so one listen is 500g /  = ~680g/hour

So to reach carbon-parity, you’d need to listen to the record for 500g / 0.045g/hour = 11,111 hours, or 11,111 / 44/60 = ~15k plays

1098004035959803905.text: Which means each person is responsible for 1.9kg CO2 / 25k users = 72g of CO2/user, for 2 months of continuous streaming (1.6k hours/music)

1098003395019923456.text:
Assuming a server draws 1Kwh*, that means it could run for 1.6Mwh/1Kwh = 1,600 hours = ~66 days.

Which doesn’t seem great… but also consider: in those 66 days, it could be streaming music continually to ~25k** people at a time.

*: source: educated guess
**: also educated guess

Consider, ex, if you notice that a view in your webapp is, on average, slow.

Your investigation will be very different if:
- 95% of requests take 100ms and 5% take 10s
- all requests take about 1s

930179730136907777.text: For just about any dataset you could analyze, “all the values are about the same” means something very different from “values are very different”.

930178617832751106.text:
It’s incredibly important to consider the distribution of any data being averaged, and (modulo bad tools) it isn’t hard to do:
- plot the standard deviation, 75/90/95th percentile, or even min/max along with the mean
- create a histogram
- scroll trough and eyeball it

930176909140426752.text:
It consistently baffles me when graphing tools show an average without any hint of the data’s distribution.

Ex, @NewRelic shows which tasks are, on average, slowest… but not whether that’s an average of “some very slow, many fast” or “all are equally slow”
